sub_topic: Prove that every group of prime order is cyclic.
message_1: What is the generator of a group of prime order 7?
message_2:
A generator of a group of prime order 7 is an element that generates all the non-identity elements of the group when raised to successive powers. In other words, if the group is G and the generator is g, then the elements {g, g^2, g^3, g^4, g^5, g^6} are all distinct and form the non-identity elements of G.

For example, in the multiplicative group of integers modulo 7, denoted as (Z/7Z)*, the generators are 3 and 5. This is because:

3^1 ≡ 3 (mod 7)
3^2 ≡ 2 (mod 7)
3^3 ≡ 6 (mod 7)
3^4 ≡ 4 (mod 7)
3^5 ≡ 5 (mod 7)
3^6 ≡ 1 (mod 7)

and

5^1 ≡ 5 (mod 7)
5^2 ≡ 4 (mod 7)
5^3 ≡ 6 (mod 7)
5^4 ≡ 2 (mod 7)
5^5 ≡ 3 (mod 7)
5^6 ≡ 1 (mod 7)

So, the generators of a group of prime order 7 are 3 and 5 in the case of the multiplicative group of integers modulo 7. Note that the specific generators may vary depending on the group in question.
